title: 111_hr3901
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" is aimed at enhancing the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces an age limitation for claiming the tax credit on the purchase of a residence. Taxpayers must be at least 18 years old at the time of purchase, or if married, either spouse must meet the age requirement. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces an age limitation for claiming the tax credit on the purchase of a residence. Taxpayers must meet the age requirement, and there are amendments to the documentation requirement in the tax code. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces changes to the tax code, including adding a new paragraph regarding the failure to attach a settlement statement to the tax return. There is also a restriction on married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse. Additionally, certain errors related to the first-time homebuyer tax credit are treated as mathematical or clerical errors. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces changes to the tax code, including errors related to the first-time homebuyer tax credit being treated as mathematical or clerical errors. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces changes to the tax code, including requirements for taxpayer eligibility for the credit. The taxpayer must meet age requirements, provide consistent information on income tax returns, and attach the necessary form to the return. The amendments made by the "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" apply to purchases and returns after the date of enactment. The amendments made by subsection (d) of the Act apply to returns for taxable years ending on or after April 9, 2008. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Certain tax return preparers must file individual income tax returns on magnetic media if they are specified tax return preparers for that calendar year. Certain tax return preparers must file individual income tax returns on magnetic media if they are specified tax return preparers for the calendar year, unless they expect to file 100 or fewer individual income tax returns. The term 'individual income tax return' refers to any return of tax imposed on individuals, estates, or trusts. A conforming amendment states that the Secretary may not, except as provided in paragraph (3). These amendments apply to returns filed after December 31, 2010.
